entries.meaning: (historical) Alternative form of Hanse, a merchant guild or a former commercial league of German cities.
examples: The town does not seem to have had a hanse, nor have there been discovered any records showing the existence of medieval trade guilds;  […]

entries.meaning: (historical) A fee payable to the Hanse, particularly its entrance fee and the impost levied on non-members trading in its area.

description: Compare French anse (“handle”), anse de panier (“surbased arch, flat arch, vault”), and English haunch (“hip”).

entries.meaning: (architecture) That part of an elliptical or many-centred arch which has the shorter radius and immediately adjoins the impost.
examples: Now Workmen call each End of these Arches the Hanse, which Hanses are always the Arches of smaller Circles than the Scheme, which is the middle Part of these Arches, and consists of a Part of a larger Circle  […]
